verses.text: With three things my spirit is pleased, and they are approved before both God and men: unity among brothers, friendship between neighbors, and a wife in harmony with her husband.
verses.comment: This verse highlights key virtues: brotherly unity, friendship, and marital harmony. These lay the foundation for peace within God's community. The emphasis on harmony in marriage has connections with the creation account, where union is central (Gen. 2:24).

verses.text: But my soul hates three kinds of people, and I am greatly offended by their way of life: a poor man who is arrogant, a rich man who is a liar, and an old adulterer lacking in understanding.
verses.comment: These three vices—pride in poverty, deceit in wealth, and foolish immorality in old age—are presented as violations of the divine order. The condemnation of arrogance and deceit reflects traditional wisdom teachings (Prov. 16:18).

verses.text: If you have not gathered in your youth, how will you find anything in your old age?
verses.comment: Diligence and foresight in youth are urged as the wise path. The ant’s example is echoed here (Prov. 6:6-8), suggesting preparation is necessary to secure one’s future, both spiritually and materially.

verses.text: How beautiful is sound judgment in gray-haired men, and wise counsel in elders!
verses.comment: This statement upholds reverence for elders, seeing wisdom as a crown of glory for those of age. This wisdom was crucial for passing down truth through the generations (Lev. 19:32).

verses.text: How excellent is the experience of aged men, and the one who seeks advice from those older than himself!
verses.comment: The author stresses the value in seeking counsel from those advanced in years, recognizing their insight. This is consistent with the biblical pattern of intergenerational faith learning.

verses.text: Wisdom is the crown of aged men, and their glory is the fear of the Lord.
verses.comment: Here, wisdom and fear of the Lord are closely linked (Prov. 1:7). Spiritual maturity together with reverent awe for God produces true honor among God’s people.

verses.text: Nine things I have considered happy in my heart, and a tenth I will speak with my tongue: a man who rejoices in his children; one who lives to see the fall of his enemies;
verses.comment: The list that follows gives examples of happiness, echoing wisdom traditions and the beatitudes. Here, joy in family is consistent with Old Testament blessing (Ps. 127:3-5).

verses.text: A man who lives with a prudent wife; one who does not stumble with his tongue; one who has not served a man inferior to himself;
verses.comment: Wise marital choice and careful speech are signs of a blessed life. The New Testament also emphasizes the need to control one’s tongue (Jas. 3:2).

verses.text: One who has found wisdom—yes, even one who speaks before attentive listeners.
verses.comment: Finding wisdom is greatly blessed (Prov. 3:13). Speaking before an audience that listens points to the dignity of sharing God’s truths, prefiguring the importance of preaching and teaching in the community.

verses.text: How great is the one who finds wisdom! Yet no one is greater than the one who fears the Lord.
verses.comment: This verse places fear of the Lord above even wisdom itself—a key biblical theme. True wisdom flows from reverence for God.

verses.text: Fear of the Lord surpasses all else; those who possess it will be compared to nothing.
verses.comment: Once again the priority of the fear of God is underlined. Reverent awe and humility before God are valued above all earthly treasures.

verses.text: Any plague but the plague of the heart, any wickedness but a woman’s wickedness!
verses.comment: The author warns particularly of dangers to the heart (the center of the person). The theme of relational harmony and warning against causing division in the household is common in wisdom literature.

verses.text: Any evil is small compared to the evil of a woman; may the fate of sinners come upon her!
verses.comment: Vivid language here is consistent with ancient wisdom’s warnings. The point is to avoid bitterness and discord in the household. The theme is not misogynistic in context, as later chapters extol the virtuous woman (Sir. 26:1).

verses.text: As the sand that sinks to the bottom is to the feet of the aged, so is a talkative wife to a quiet man.
verses.comment: A proverb-style observation. The aim is to encourage harmony and restraint in speech. The New Testament’s call for mutual respect in marriage (Eph. 5:21-33) provides a fuller context.

verses.text: Do not be ensnared by the beauty of a woman, or long for her beauty.
verses.comment: The fleeting nature of outward beauty is a warning to value virtue above physical appearance. Jesus echoes this in Matt. 5:28, warning against lustful intent and emphasizing purity of heart.

verses.text: Anger, insult, and shame can come with a woman who brings her husband low. Weak hands and feeble knees are caused by her.
verses.comment: The harm caused by a destructive relationship is noted as debilitating. By contrast, the virtuous spouse strengthens and upholds (Prov. 12:4).

verses.text: A woman does not gladden her husband’s heart; instead, her hands cause his feet to stumble.
verses.comment: Disorder in marriage is a source of sorrow and difficulty for a man, a recurring theme in wisdom literature. Mutual support is the biblical ideal.

verses.text: From a woman’s wickedness, the beginning of sin, and because of her, we all die.
verses.comment: This refers to the Fall (Gen. 3), with Eve’s role in humanity’s first disobedience. Paul expands this in Romans 5:12, showing that all people—men and women—inherit original sin. This sets the stage for the need for redemption through Christ’s work.

verses.text: Do not let your water be spilled, nor your spring let out to a stranger.
verses.comment: ‘Water’ and ‘spring’ are metaphors for marital fidelity. This is a warning to guard the sanctity of marriage, paralleling wisdom in Proverbs.

verses.text: If she will not walk under your hand, cut her off from your flesh.
verses.comment: This is an allusion to divorce laws as found in Deuteronomy, but read in the context of the entire biblical narrative, Jesus reaffirms the sacredness and indissolubility of marriage (Matt. 19:6), calling the community back to God’s original design.

verses.text: Every wickedness is small compared to a woman’s wickedness; may the lot of sinners fall on her!
verses.comment: This repeated theme intensifies the general warning against vice and disharmony, urging the community to prize virtue above all in household life. Later wisdom texts balance this with praise for the virtuous woman (Prov. 31).

verses.text: As a climbing sandhill for the feet of the aged, so is a wife full of words to a quiet man.
verses.comment: A metaphor for the strain caused by disharmony. The emphasis is again on the blessing of peace within marriage, valued in both Testaments.

verses.text: Do not be ensnared by a woman’s beauty or desire her for her looks.
verses.comment: This repeats the warning to prioritize inner virtue rather than outward beauty in choosing whom to trust and honor.

verses.text: A woman, if she maintains her superiority, is contrary to the order of creation; but a man who yields to her will face sorrow and disgrace.
verses.comment: This verse speaks to the need for proper order in the household, reflecting Genesis. The biblical vision of marriage is one of complementarity and mutual support, not domination (cf. Eph. 5:21-33).

verses.text: A wicked woman causes a downcast face and a gloomy heart, and hands too weak for any good work.
verses.comment: Negative influence in the household can even affect one’s spiritual life and productivity. The Scripture invites the pursuit of sanctity in every relationship, with later chapters showing the joy brought by godly partnership.

verses.text: Because of a woman, sin began, and because of her, we all die.
verses.comment: This final phrase points back to the Fall (Gen. 3; Rom. 5), underscoring the doctrine of original sin. The narrative prepares the way for the coming Redeemer, who will reverse the effects of the first disobedience (cf. Rom. 5:18-19). Through Christ, the community is invited into a new order of grace and harmony, restored through faith, sacramental living, and ongoing transformation.
